Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2021

Review Title: Nice picture, great integration with smart home systems
Review Text: Oooooh, how bad I wanted to give this a great review.  However.... First the back story. I don't like paying fees to monitor my own home. I'm tech savvy enough that I've installed several security cameras without ever paying fees. I buy open source devices and manage them on my router. But I digress...  I initially had a Skybell because they were the only ones on the market without having to pay monthly fees. The Skybell's picture was beautiful and again, no fees. But there were instances where the app took a long time to open a video stream and sometimes not at all. Plus, it didn't have any smart home integration (Alexa). Which brings me back to the Blink video doorbell. It was on sale a few months back, so I thought I'd try it out. I already had a couple of Blink wireless cameras, which I only tried because they were on a great sale as well. To be clear, the Blink system, much like most of the security cameras available are p2p type cameras. Meaning, you have to use the app from the camera company. And you cannot view them using a pc.  One thing that made the Blink system stand out was the Sync Module, which acts like a mini router, or hub of sorts. There is the option of inserting a usb thumb drive so to save videos and pictures locally and not just the cloud. The cloud is why there are fees btw. So, the monthly fee is optional to not only view the cameras, but to play back videos. All this sounds great, right? Well, when trying to view the doorbell, as well as the wireless cameras I already had, there is an exorbitant amount of time to open a video stream. I mean, like 10 seconds, which may not seem long. But when someone is waiting at the door... I never thought it would take so long to open a video stream. I spent time on the phone with customer service, ran several tests, and the only thing they came back with is that because my router is dual band, the doorbell was having difficulty navigating the airwaves filled with both the 2.4ghz and 5ghz band waves. What whaaat?  The router system I have happens to be the eero mesh router system...another Amazon company!  The eero unfortunately does not offer the ability to split the 2 bands, or even turn off the 5ghz, which I made sure to complain about to the eero folks. So, this whole long review to say that I'm unfortunately going to have to go back to the drawing board, swallow the cost, and find another option. Thanks for listening. 😉
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2022

Review Title: Best and most flexible video doorbell for the money - Hands down!
Review Text: For under $50, this is the best video doorbell going.  You can wire it to your existing doorbell wiring and have it ring your electro-mechanical or electronic door chime or you can go totally wireless.  It's up to you.  Setup is easy and if you have an existing Blink account, it is added like any other blink camera.  Video quality is superb (better than the other Blink/XT cameras I have).  If you have an existing free Blink account with the original sync module, you can use your free cloud storage so there is no monthly free.  If not, you must pay for cloud storage, use it without a sync module or purchase a sync 2 module and you can store to the SD card if you want to avoid the monthly fee.I opted to wire mine to the existing door bell wiring and the installation came out great.  There are a few downsides to this doorbell but it is still the best option for most people.  The doorbell uses battery power even if hard wired so don't loose the special tool for removing it as you will have to replace batteries periodically.  Like other Blink cameras, you can't do continuous live views.  When you live view, you will get a "Continue" popup every 25 seconds.  If you don't press continue, the view will stop.  Alexa integration is not reliable but it works flawlessly with the Blink app.  You can set all the usual things for the motion detection like activity zones, privacy zones, sensitivity, clip length, resolution, re-trigger delay, and you can set the recording to end when motion stops even if clip length has not elapsed.  When someone rings the doorbell, you can talk to them via your phone even if you are not home.  The system has the features of the more expensive ring models at a fraction of the cost and the motion detection is better.If you have been considering a video doorbell but have been on the fence, pull the trigger on this one.  You won't regret it.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2022

Review Title: Great Video Doorbell especially with Alexa Devices
Review Text:
The media could not be loaded.
                




   I have been looking at video doorbells for a number of years, and have always found a reason to hold off buying them. Part of my reasoning is I already have Blink XT2 security cameras, I already have a number of Alexa devices, why would I want to add one more infrastructure to my smart home environment? Then I saw that Blink finally released their version of a video doorbell and it was able to connect to both the old Blink sync module (I have one of the old ones and have one of the free 2hours storage accounts pre-2020) and the newer Sync 2 modules, as well as connect to Alexa to do a number of things.Let's start the with basics. Installation is pretty simple, they even include a template to mark the wall for drilling and mounting. Two screws to mount the bracket to the wall. I also used a 30˚ bracket in addition to the standard back plate which comes with no directions but it is pretty simple to figure out. The system will allow you to connect to existing doorbell  (16v - 24v) wiring if you have an existing doorbell chime, which I did not. Once you have the back plate mounted you can then hang the doorbell. NOTE: Do not mount the door bell until after you have added it to your Sync module and your Blink app since you will need the barcode on the back in order to join it. Adding the doorbell to the mount does require you apply pressure towards the back plate, and then slide it down about 1/32" to lock it into place. There are a number of reasons for this, including there is a gasket between the doorbell and the back plate that is there to keep moisture out, and you need to compress this while you slide it into place.Once you have it up and running you can add it to your Alexa devices using the Blink Skill and use any Echo to work as your doorbell chime. I originally enabled them all realized that it made sense to only have a few of them respond when the doorbell is pushed because it was very jarring to have every room in my house blasting with a chime and the announcement of "Someone is at Your Front Door". Also if you have an Echo Show you can preview the doorbell, and any of the other cameras on the display screen.Overall the video and audio quality is good for what it is, and the Android app works perfectly with the devices. It is easy to view recorded interactions, and download the files from the cloud to the phone. After installing this at my house I also added one with a Sync 2 module at my girlfriends house, and she loved the benefits of having one, which all prompted her to have me add two more security cameras.I would highly recommend this system, keeping in mind the following:- You need to have a Sync module to make this actually work because of how the video is accessed.- You do not need a preexisting doorbell chime and transformer, but if you have one you can hook into it.- If you do not have a doorbell Chime can use an Amazon Echo device to work as one if not you will only get the notifications on your phone.- No mater how you hook it up, you will need to have the batteries installed to power the camera, and currently there is no way to hardware and power the system even if it is hooked up to a doorbell transformer.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2022

Review Text: I've been using 3 blink cameras with local storage (and no cloud subscription) for several months now with no issues. I installed the video doorbell on 10/29 and things initially worked fine (motion detection and recording to the free trial cloud subscription and to local storage). The next day, I cancelled the free trial as it wasn't needed and things seemed to be working fine. From that point on, the doorbell's motion detection and recording no longer worked. I could do everything else: live view, take a photo, change settings, answer a doorbell ring, but motion detection and recording no longer worked.I took the doorbell off the mount and removed the batteries to perform a "hard reset" but no luck. Email tech support was useless. After going thru basics like changing the recording clip length and 'are you sure motion detection is enabled?', I ran their special app to troubleshoot network issues.  Their recommendations were to disable the router firewall and to give separate names to the two frequency bands on my dual band router.I told them I was not going to disable the firewall as this was a basic security issue and besides, the 3 blink cameras had been working fine for months with my network configuration (and continue to do so).Having read in AnInSe's review that all videos first go to Blink's servers before being transferred to local storage, I believe there is a bug on the server side that prevents videos from going to local storage if you cancel the trial cloud subscription.**UPDATE**Three hours after posting this review, my doorbell's motion detection and recording started working after having been inoperable for three days. I did nothing on my end to fix it. I did not disable my firewall or set up separate network names for my dual band router as tech support had recommended. I had just left it mounted and running, hoping that it was either a firmware issue in the doorbell or a server side issue that Blink would eventually fix. Apparently they did.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2021

Review Text: I don't wanna praise it too high just yet because I have only used it for couple weeks. Easy to set up by following simple instructions. I hard wired it but initially it says to insert batteries. After that it doesn't say to remove batteries or not so I left them installed. I would prefer that the scan code also be put on the box it came with incase I had to reset in the future. You will have to pull it off the wall if you ever have to scan the code on the back of the doorbell.I tested it on my doorbell wire and received a warning that the voltage was too low. My thinking is that a lower voltage is better than too high of one so I left it hard wired.Alerts early enough and almost too sensitive. I think the sensitivity can be adjusted on your phone app. I set it up to my Alexa through the Alexa app and home security feature. I can't see a constant picture display like on my other blink cameras (just a blank screen) but when I open the app, video will turn on and also when someone is at the door. A signal is sent to your phone first.I can answer the door through my phone but it makes a high pitched sound and tough to understand. If I tell Alexa to " show my doorbell" the TV turns on and doorbell video can be observed ( I like this feature).  Alerts go off alot at night so I put it on silent or turn off. It catches all the passing cars on my street. Night vision is ok as most cameras only display black and white but I can still make out who or what is out front. You get a cloud account to try for 30 days and is compatible with your existing blink system. I will use a USB stick when my trial is over but I have not had a drop in signal or any problems with it since I installed this item. I recommend this to anyone since I have enjoyed it so much. Great item to purchase for Christmas. One last point is that I can not adjust the volume on the doorbell chime but I can have it in sequence with my hardwired chime. A ++
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2021

Review Text: We had a Ring video doorbell and after 14 months of constant problems, finally decided to go with Blink. I should have done so 6 months ago, as our Blink security cameras have been flawless for 4 years, only changing the batteries every 20-24 months. And Blink customer service is amazing, vs Ring not so much.The Blink doorbell integrates into the Blink security system flawlessly and, unlike the Ring, can be scheduled on and off, whereas the Ring only allows scheduling motion detection off. The Blink installs easily and will ring the mechanical doorbell with the button press. I really like the innovation where you can match the doorbell transformer voltage to the Blink and thus get either a single chime or the familiar "ding-dong" sound at each button press.Sensitivity is very good day and night, and video quality is also very good. I have to admit the Ring appeared to have slightly better night video quality, but also did not have the ability to adjust the IR illuminator like the Blink does. I will adjust it to high and see if that improves the video.Installation is easy, and I used the corner bracket to improve visibility toward the front steps as the doorbell wiring is on a side wall. Setup is also easy and the Blink app guides you through the installation. If you have a Blink Sync Module for other cameras you do not have to purchase a new module; the doorbell will run off any other sync module you already have. You can run up to 10 devices off one module, although we do use separate modules for certain cameras to have the flexibility to schedule them individually rather than in groups. Plus if your previous Blink system is "grandfathered" as ours is, there is no annual fee for cloud storage. Even at the $30 annual fee, it is no more expensive than others.I am very pleased with this doorbell. It is a great addition to our home and security.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2022

Review Title: Misleading marketing material and underwhelming video
Review Text: I purchased the Blink video doorbell to replace another video doorbell that offered a similar feature set and local storage.  Having owned a similar doorbell gives me the ability to compare and contrast basic features.Video quality:I was disappointed with the video quality, especially if zooming in on an image, as the image gets grainy.  Even when unzoomed it just does not show the level of detail that my previous doorbell did (picture for reference)Field of vision:This has more of a wide angle lens, so if you have a wide entranceway this may be beneficial.  However, I personally prefer the fisheye lens that my previous doorbell had, as it allowed me to view if I had any packages sitting on my door step (picture for reference)Notifications:Although the app can be unreliable with showing badge notifications, the push notifications showing motion detection and a doorbell push are almost instantaneous.Visibility of doorbell:This was a disappointment, as the marketing material that shows the blue light ring constantly lit is extremely misleading.  The blue light ring only lights briefly when the doorbell is pushed and does not stay on constantly.  Perhaps this is for the purpose of saving battery life, as the power is solely received from the batteries regardless if you also have it hard-wired.  However, I would at least like to have the option of keeping it on all the time for visibility so my wanted visitors know it's there to push and my unwanted visitors know they are being recorded.If Blink is willing to read customer reviews and make some hardware and software changes, I'd be happy to re-visit my review with updates.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2021

Review Title: Spare yourself-do not buy. Technical issues for some and abysmally bad customer support.
Review Text: I’ve spent almost a month trying to get the two doorbells and camera that I purchased to work properly. The pros:1. Integration with Alexa is seamless2. motion detection works well if the doorbell is installed at the right angleCons (and they are numerous):1. They’ve used the a chip that responds to both 2.4 and 5G although the doorbells will only work on 2.4. What does this mean? If you’ve got a router that will not separate your 2.4 and 5G bandwidths into different WiFi networks, you’re screwed. For example, if you rent a newish router from Spectrum, one of the largest ISPs in the country, you cannot set up two separate Wi-Fi’s. The doorbell will become confused, working sporadically but not fully. In my case live view will not work nor will the option to speak with visitors (or package thieves). Yes, I saw that the blink system only works on 2.4. However I have several other things that only function on 2.4 and do so with no problem. Furthermore, the fact that it only functions on 2.4 is only listed if you click on “technical details”. The description should be clear that since Blink used cheap chips that respond to both 5G and 2.4, you have to be able to separate those bandwidths in your home for it to function properly.  Be aware, the tech support reps will tell you that “of course you can separate them on the router from Spectrum” as though you’re an idiot for saying you can’t. Nope. You CANNOT and spectrum cannot. Some newer routers do not have that capability.2. They are not clear on everything you will give up if you choose not to subscribe to their cloud storage. Makes the gadgets significantly less useful and feels very much like bait and switch.3. Image quality is pretty shoddy, but this may be a function of the device being confused and trying to function on 5G.3. Customer service and tech support at Blink are PROFOUNDLY inept, disinterested, lackadaisical and occasionally just plain rude. I spent 5 hours between Blink and Spectrum tonight trying to make this system finally work. For the record, they are not available 24/7 because they’re too busy. You’ll get a VM and a hang up if you request tech support. You’ll need to keep calling and punch the option for new set up. Don’t expect them to act at all apologetic for reneging on the 24/7 statement.After multiple call attempts, Rep 1 repeatedly told me to go to the settings to subscribe to their stupidly expensive $10/month plan, seemingly incapable of understanding that I would first like to see if the doorbells can be made to function correctly. I said it 3 times. It’s not a tough concept.Rep #2 also had a listening problem. When I asked her to please stop interrupting me (so she could fix a problem I actually had rather than one I didn’t), she just hung up. Nice.Rep #3 sounded like he was answering the call from bed and insisted I was wrong and that Spectrum could separate the 2.4 and 5G. He said rather snottily that other customers hadn’t called saying it was an issue. Um yeah….maybe because they lost patience and returned the piece of garbage? He also felt the need to inform me more than once that the listing says 2.4. Really? Take a look at the Amazon listing. ONLY if you read the technical specs.Lastly, I’ve been on with Blink customer support at least 8 times. Why is it that none of their reps could solve this over the course of a month and a Spectrum tech support guy had to be the one to explain it? I now have a choice of installing a new router that spectrum won’t support if the internet goes out or returning these trashy devices. Not a hard choice. Other makers of wireless video doorbells use chips that only respond to the one frequency. I’ll replace it with one of those from a company that hopefully knows what it’s doing. I am furious at the incompetence and rudeness displayed as well as poor quality of this product. This company is a nasty joke that’s wasted hours of my time. Bit surprised they’re owned by Amazon. Why on earth did they buy Blink and why haven’t they cleaned up this joke of a company?
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2022

Review Text: I read a lot of reviews before purchase & install… so I expected problems with the mount, wiring to existing chime, and adding to existing pre 2020 blink system. Ironically it took me longer to “make” a wooden adaptor for my door trim than it did to physically install the device. Some key things I learned along the way (1) when adding to your existing system, add the doorbell to the system assigned to the sync module, this will be the group with your other XT or XT2 cameras(my legacy cameras). At first I added a new system within the app and named it “doorbells” as I planned to install 2 of them. Within the app my new “doorbells” system was not linked to the sync module so the device was in “event response” mode (press the doorbell to save changes etc) and had limited features. Once I switched it to my “outdoor” system along with all of my other sync module cameras everything worked as desired. (2) I voltage tested my 2002 existing door chime at 19.8 volts and wired the blink doorbell with no problem… but then the chime would not activate after pressing the button… yes, you need to use the app to finish the install. I had skipped the mount and wiring step to install it in the app first upon delivery the night before… Once I followed the steps in the app everything works as expected. (3) the mount works well but does require a firm flat surface (numerous reviews are not wrong). Since I wanted to use existing wiring that was run thru the door trim, I pieced together an adaptor with some scrap wood to make a flat surface. Gently position the doorbell over and slightly above the tabs on the plate, press against the mounting plate and slide down. An audible click lets you know it is locked in. While trying to get the chime to sound inside… I removed and replaced it several times with no problem. Also, despite the app indicating “external power” the batteries are required (as numerous reviews indicate). Also the blue ring only illuminates when pressed (again the reviews are not wrong). I was hopeful that motion would cause illumination, but no go. Too bad… maybe a software update will resolve this? Everything I read about the “photo capture” function indicates you need a subscription… yet I had a camera roll video this morning identified by the blue “camera” icon in the clip roll on my original sync module system… unknown if the video clip was actually hourly snapshots as the camera was facing down on the coffee table all night… will see what happens tomorrow.Update 12/13 the Photo Capture feature does work with the doorbell in the pre 2020 system (original sync module).
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2021

Review Title: Impressive if you follow the directions!
Review Text: So after waiting an EXTRA long time to get the white Blink Video Doorbell, I set out to install it in place of my existing doorbell.  I already knew I had a low voltage system so no worries there.  Doorbells aren't complicated.  It's a simple switch that closes a circuit to trigger the ringer.  Blink allows the installation in a wired or wireless format. The wireless install is no different than any other Blink camera.Installation was pretty straightforward but getting the mount to "lock" into the doorbell took some persuasion.  There's no positive "click" feeling when the mount and camera are fully seated.  After hastily removing my old doorbell button and hooking up the Blink, I didn't understand why it wasn't working.  Lo and behold, during the initial addition of the Video Doorbell to your system hub, there's a walkthrough on setting it up.  I skipped that because I got interrupted by something else (squirrel!) and didn't realize it was an important step.So once I was sure everything was mounted correctly, I went into the Video Doorbell settings and configured it for a powered, mechanical chime.  The doorbell firmware did its thing and got everything working correctly.  Very nice, Blink devs.The video quality is exceptional and it's super wide angle.  The motion sensitivity is great and it catches cars going by over 50 feet away.  Night vision is excellent.There is some delay on the talk/listen feature, however.  I would argue that it's almost unusable but will hold out judgment until I've used it a little more.  It is, however, clear and very functional.Amazon provided a coupon code for the wedge mount because it wasn't included with the first run of these units.  Thanks, Amazon.I had been tracking this for what seems like years and I'm happy Amazon/Blink finally released it.  I'd argue that it's the pinnacle of my ten camera Blink installation.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2021

Review Title: Read reviews BEFORE installing— make sure screws on mounting plate are tight/plate does not wiggle
Review Text: I’ve had multiple indoor and outdoor Blink cameras for years, so adding the Blink doorbell made the best sense for me.  In addition to added security, I was interested in the ability to know who and when someone was at the front door as I can’t hear folks knocking from the upper level or back of the house.I’m a very handy person who requires little instruction to figure things out.  This thing had me puzzled for about an hour as to why it wouldn’t simply click together.  It’s clear from the design how the parts are to connect… but they don’t just snap together for testing or confirming you are assembling/installing correctly.Initial installation of the doorbell left it barely in the mount and ready to fall off with the slightest touch— obviously not ideal for how a doorbell is used. Just before I was ready click the send button for a product complaint to Blink (they provided excellent service with a camera issue in the past), I did some research on Amazon reviews.  The one that says something like “read this first” helped me solve the problem.Part of the issue was that I had left just a little bit of give in the screws to make it easier to remove the mounting plate if something was wrong with placement or installation. 1) The screws to the mounting plate must be tight!  When you are ready to place the doorbell into the plate, 2) look at the plate from the side (if possible) to help line up the back of the doorbell with the small cleats on the plate 3) hold the doorbell slightly above the cleats 4) push hard towards the plate and down to lock the cleats in.  There isn’t a tell tale click sound… but when it’s in there… you will know because it is definitely tightly affixed.So far, it’s working very well.  The only other thing I would add is to check the view the doorbell provides before you install it.  Check to make sure there are minimal to no obstructions so you can maximize the security features.  Also look for options that give you the view you need.  For example, if you’re wanting to keep an eye on packages on the front step, you may need to place it a little lower than you might think to.Like my other Blink products, adding the doorbell to my system and the rest of the installation process was easy.  Having an older home and not wanting to spend hundred of dollars on wiring…I appreciate the ability to place and move these cameras wherever I need to with the non-wired options.  Overall, I’m happy with my purchase.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2021

Review Text: *Edit* Updating this review since the doorbell automagically started working the day I went to uninstall it. Right before I took it off I told myself to try it one more time and lo and behold.. it worked. Tried it several more times and it has worked every time. I had made sure it was up to date with it’s firmware and software as soon as I had installed it, so I know that wasn’t what fixed it, but something happened and now it seems okay. Also, someone from Blink saw this review and contacted me to see if they could assist, with I was glad to see, but didn’t need their assistance since it apparently fixed itself. I’m going to leave this as a two star rating for another week or so just to be sure before updating it to 4 stars.Original review-  Just installed the doorbell and everything went smoothly. It added to my system no problem. Build quality looks nice. It detected my voltage for the mechanical chime and rang the bell without an issue. Great! So far so good… until I actually tried to use it. I press the button and get the notification on my phone almost immediately. When I tap the notification though… it takes me into the app and shows me a spinning gear…. Forever. It never goes to a live view. It never shows me the recorded view. It just spins. Endlessly.After I exit the app, I can go back in and select live view and that works great. But it NEVER works from the notification when someone presses the button. It’s “busy”.  This is a terrible implementation and I can’t believe a company like blink has this sort of problem. I tried to email them about it but “ran into an error” when sending the email from the support link.  If support can’t get this squared away, I’ll return it and get a Ring, which I really don’t want to do, but I know their stuff works.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2022

Review Title: Wait. For a while, or forever. This is not the doorbell you're looking for.
Review Text: Let's start with the obvious reason to buy this doorbell: Integration with the Alexa ecosystem you already have in your house. For me I have Echo's, Echo Show, Blink Inside/Outside cameras(6 total), Halo Fitness Tracker(not really connected but still Amazon).Out of the box, batteries in, connect to the blink app-easy. Scan a bar code and good to go. Get a warning about having a Sync Module? No problem I have it.Doorbell "No you don't".Um..yes I do, all of the cameras could tell you the same.So first red flag is it refuses to acknowledge my sync module.  A handful of powering off module, router, camera in different combinations-it finally seems to see it....ok first 40 minutes gone.Next remove the Ring doorbell that's hardwired in with no issues in a full year of use to wire in the Blink doorbell. "Your transformer doesn't seem to be compatible". Hmmm...double check the fine print, specs, requirements..yeah-yeah it is. Ok, kill the breaker, unhook, re-hook, breaker on...nope...Hook the ring doorbell back up(requires the exact same power as Blink)-works fine.Ok...so poof bang pow(get the blink wired back up, reset router and sync module) "your transformer is perfect! way to go big guy".Alrighty...Alexa app shows video, Echo Show-video check. Neat.Now for the purpose...ring the doorbell...crickets chirp...So 60+ minutes into it I go back through all the settings, test chime works fine, bell chimes on the doorbell itself, but not outside the app or the doorbell. Triple check settings...Echo's enabled as chimes...Reset router, sync module again...and again.75th time is the charm! It finally works....kinda? 90 minutes in...The shortest latency period I could manage was 43 seconds from doorbell push to echo notifications.Go ahead...hold your breath for 43 seconds...see if you're hanging out at my door that long before I even know you're there.My sync module, wireless router, anything that matters are all centrally located in my home, over 150mb speed even at the heaviest of streaming/download times. My Ring doorbell has zero issues. It does everything the Blink camera does(but actually does them). It only requires me to have an extra app on my phone.Save your time and hold off until Amazon wants to ship a functioning doorbell.(Before jumping to conclusions on my level of interaction with support staff....yes all the power up/down/unplug/plug-in, reset app, delete doorbell, hard reset module, is what hoops you'll be jumping through).
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2021

Review Title: So! I wanted to love these & just a as door bell cam GREAT but other wise no I'll tell you why
Review Text: I previously purchased 2 rings at a deal & had finally got them programmed to catch movement on the street etc. I sold the home & left them as agreed. I was trying to be cheap & purchased blink instead. the clips are so short & pretty much right at the door, you have to go ring the bell for any change to take effect - annoying!! It says if not it takes 24hrs. I made some changes & have had no movement since 430p yesterday.  Also they are hard to open/close for batteries (2-AA lithium only) The ring it so easy to attach & charges with a cord. I never bothered with the security screws, I just lift it off to charge & stick it back. I was considering  calling support to see if I can work out some issues but I think I've talked myself into definite return instead. Also show announces it by its long serial# vs what I have it named and it knows the name.. Motion at hfydytdtudduduktdk-321654654vb so annoying! lol.  If you need something at this price point budget , its worth it for $39.  Put one on the back door too. You may have to get creative to hang it because its like a childproof pill bottle but worse because you cant get the lid back on either. If you have extra funds go w/ring. Either way get something & do the paid service before the trial runs out. You need this service in these times. <3
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on March 10, 2022

Review Text: I bought this to replace a hardwired doorbell, wanting the visual deterrence with no actual monitoring.  A "video" doorbell is visible before walking up the driveway, unlike a fake camera.1) The Q&A response I received that the blue light will illuminate when hardwired, with no App setup needed, is false.  My doorbell wires measure 18.6V, which should be fine according to the documentation, but I get no blue light and no doorbell chime.  I suppose it's possible my Blink doorbell simply doesn't work.2) I can't get the box to snap onto the back plate, so even if #1 weren't an issue, the one I received wouldn't actually be usable.  (I pushed the box snug against the plate to test functionality.  The contacts should have been making full contact as such; I simply couldn't get the lower tab to snap in place.  Very cheap design.)3) The tiny plastic tabs that lock the box to the back plate do not feel like they'll last through many removals (if using batteries instead of hardwiring), especially in an outdoor environment with temperature swings.  Consider this typical disposable goods from you know where.4) The packaging was designed for, or perhaps by, someone who enjoys unboxing videos way too much.  No one needs that many complex little cardboard flaps to untangle.5) The included instructions don't mention the key card thingy, but the online instructions say, "A paper template is included with your doorbell to show where the mounting holes are placed. The template is shipped with the doorbell opening key attached."  The paper template is of no use, as the backing plate does the same thing.  This fits with #4, wasted packaging.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2021

Review Text: Unfortunately, I am not impressed by the product so far.  It has many shortcomings that make it a useless product.Issue 1:  The iPhone application does not provide an audible chime/sound/alert when the doorbell button is pressed. The only notification provided is a text notification.  So, if you are not looking at your phone's screen, you will never know that somebody just rang the doorbell!!!Issue 2:  There is no chime add-on device available from the company.  The only option is to use an existing chime device from your wired doorbell.  This defeats the wireless installation.  Our hose never had a wired doorbell. So, this along with the previous issue I mentioned makes the product useless.Issue 3: The camera coverage is very bad.  I am not sure how the product website shows a picture of packages on the ground.  I have installed the video-doorbell directly on the front door at the height of about 4 ft above ground.  In this installation, the camera's field of view does not show anything within the 4 feet from the door. So, any packages or objects left closer than 5 ft from the door will not be visible by the camera!!! If I manually tilt the video doorbell at 45 degree angle, I can see from 2 ft away from the door. Using the optional wedge bracket is not going to be helpful either.I hope the company addresses these issues and provide better information on the limitation of the product.Good Luck.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2021

Review Title: So close but such a headache.
Review Text: I order this under preorder before reviews came out. But I did read the reviews about bad mounting over the last few weeks before it got here but kept my order today. I was hoping I would get one without the issues or with my background in Tech could find an easy fix...I can build computers and repair just about anything, But I was wrong. Sadly this product is just not ready for market. The like the software, app, and even the camera on this doorbell however the mount is the biggest miss here. This doorbell would get an easy 5 stars if the mount on the thing worked. After drilling holes and mounting it next to the front door the doorbell won't go on the mount no matter how you try it. I tried every other way to get this to fit into the hooks. Nope... If I wasn't so lazy I would return the product however I rigged the mount with double-sided tape and mounted it with command strips. Hopefully, it will hold and no one will try to rip it off. I really wanted to love this product.Update: I added another Star because the Company Service is great! They reached out to me to offer me a new mount once they are made. So I am looking forward to them sending me a new mount for this item. They really want this product to work and their service says they are willing to do what it takes to fix issues. The network went down once that created a lot of issues for me for two days however I understand those things happen with Technology. I still really like this doorbell and even ordered one for my father for Christmas. So far he seems to like it too. He didn't have any mounting issues so I and guessing it was only a few may be from the 1st batch made. Still a good product so far.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on November 9, 2021

Review Text: UPDATE:I have upgraded my review from 2 stars to 3.I agree with others that the wall mount is cumbersome. Also, it is made with plastic.I don't know about the rest of the country, but in Arizona summer heat, even in the shade those little plastic hooks will become brittle in less than a year and snap off the next time I have to replace the batteries and remount the doorbell. What will I do then?It really could have, and should have been designed better.Also, the unit still can't capture far enough down to see the ground, which is more important than being able to see 10 feet in the air. It really should have been angled down a little bit.So for now, I have to keep my Blink XT camera above the front door to check for packages left on the ground.---------------------------------------Original Review:  The unit comes with batteries and the ability to connect into the existing low voltage doorbell wiring. However, the doorbell won’t work with just the wiring alone. It requires the lithium batteries as well. Nor does it ring your house doorbell. But it does ring on your phone, so that part is good.It’s good that it works nicely with my Blink app where I have 4 Blink XT cameras being monitored.But something odd happened with a video capture the doorbell took, where it gave me like 12-15 scenes together of the change of daylight and nighttime over the course of 24 hours. Almost like a timelapse video. Why?Still waiting for my corner mount. Right now, I get a big column. (See pic)Also, the camera is high enough to where I can’t see the ground in front of the camera, for any packages left on the ground. I don’t need to see 10 feet in the air.Some improvements could be made in this doorbell.

Review Text:
The media could not be loaded.
                




   ***EDITThis thing is awful.  I can never access live view, it always fails.  I have it set where there's non trigger zones because our dogs are in view of the camera, in the front yard off to the side. Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2021

Review Title: Does not have night vision and mounting it took OVER an HOUR
Review Text: The color picture is my regular X2 that's at my doorstep--it is in color, has great picture quality even at night but doesn't have far sight range. The black and white picture is the doorbell picture at night, and if anything were to happen out in the street or in my yard, you wouldn't be able to see anything!  Now, you say it is a doorbell camera, so it is meant for usage at the door, but with it's wide angle, it picks up a lot of area, and for it to be most useful, it would be great if it had night vision like that X2s do.And mounting----I about took a hammer to the whole system I was so irate.  I spent over an hour messing with this thing.  I watched Youtube videos, read things online, texted my boyfriend who also just installed his (and he confirmed it is a pain to mount).  It just would NOT click on the back.  I uninstalled the back and went into the house and tried putting the back on while inside too.  Watched a video...showing to push it against a wall so you can use that as pressure to hold it still while clicking it on.  Nope--still wouldn't work.  Eventually I just pressed hard enough that I thought I might break it and it snapped on.  But then I couldn't get it off!  Yes, I inserted the tool, and it loosened the bottom clamp, but I still couldn't get the back off without feeling like it was going to break.  Eventually it just came apart.  IDK--by magic.  I ended up using a mounting bracket with it so that it would actually work on my wall outside.  I DREAD when I need to change the batteries.  All in all, a TERRIBLE design for the back.  There HAD to be an easier way to install--it didn't need to be so hard to install just to make it complicated to steal.  All you need is anti-thief precautions to getting it OFF the wall....but no barriers to putting it ON the wall!  The tool is a great idea.  Most thieves aren't that smart.  But I could have done without the hour of lividness trying to get it onto the wall.I give it 3 stars because it works, it syncs to my original module that I have free storage with and it does connect to Alexa, but I haven't turned that feature on because the first time that it wakes me up while I'm sleeping, I'm going to be upset.  So that feature is untested.  I will say even though I have the notifications on for the Blink app so I can get movement notifications, it randomly stopped giving notifications about a year ago--so I do not get the doorbell notifications either, and my house is large enough that I have never heard the chime when it goes off outside.I WOULD LOVE FOR YOU TO CREATE AN INSIDE CHIME BOX THAT CONNECTS TO THE SYSTEM AND YOU CAN PLUG UP ANYWHERE IN YOUR HOUSE (like the living room so it isn't right beside your face on the bedside table).  Thanks for FINALLY creating a doorbell camera though!  I was NOT going to mix and match my systems and also have RING.  Between BLINK and ADT being 2 apps to control security, I was NOT adding a 3rd!  However, Ring DOES have a chime box!
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2021

Review Title: Hope you want to get video of every car driving past your front door
Review Text: Installation was plain and simple.  I didn't have an existing doorbell, so I had to go with the battery only install (my old system was an intercom systems from days gone by, and no schematic to show how to grab required power from it).  I mounted it flush on my front door, and it was detected and integrated into Alexa with almost no problem.  Then the notices of movement started...and continued...again, and again.  During the day, I have my system armed to get motion detection on my (hardwired) Blink cameras.  The doorbell camera captured every neighbor, UPS, Fedex, Amazon, and lawn service vehicle driving by.  Annoying, and figure it'll go thru batteries at a stupid rate.  There needs to be an option to only capture motion during specific hours (I'd LOVE to know if anyone were roaming around at night, after everyone is in bed, etc.) but there doesn't seem to be the flexibility to specify times for individual devices for motion detection.  It's either on for everything or not.  Disappointing.  So for now I've disabled it, and plan to write a product request to the Blink development team, which I fully expect to be ignored, about better ways to handle motion detection.  On the positive side, when the doorbell was pressed, I did get notification on the app and via Alexa, so there's something.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2021

Review Text: The sales description was a bit confusing- so let me clarify : this unit can be used WITHOUT a subscription or additional speciality equipment - BUT after the 30 day free trial subscription expires the motion detector video service stops working unless you sign up for a $4/ month subscription. The video doorbell feature continues to function without a subscription.You download the app to your phone and follow 3 or 4 simple steps and it works - it connects to your home wireless router very easily equipment. . It will detect the motion of something at your door and send a notification to your phone. If someone presses the doorbell it will ding-dong on the door and on your phone - you can then ‘answer’ the door by talking to the person who rang the doorbell (and see them on the camera) via your phone. Or you could go old school and walk to the door and open it.The range and sensitivity of the motion detector can be adjusted so that passing cars do not trigger it.The additional equipment and subscription (confusingly) advertised enables the continued motion detection video and more advanced features it you need them.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2021

Review Text: As some noted, there is a bit of an issue with the mounting plate, but that issue can be easily fixed by reading the instructions that show how to actually mount the plate.The doorbell is generally of good quality and there isn’t a sense that it can be easily swiped, although I’m sure some thugs will prove some users wrong. Video quality is great during the day and the audio transmission is good as well. Night time video is generally just ok. The glare from the cars on the road is sometimes enough to set off the ring camera alert at night, even when you set up your active zones to monitor. So lowering the sensitivity is a must.One other thing - the chime is automatically set to off meaning if you are wiring this in place of your typical doorbell, you’ll have to go into the app and set your chime after you’ve installed the doorbell. I think that should be automatically on since…well since it’s a doorbell, but who am I to judge. It’s an easy fix.Overall I’ve been impressed with all blink products and I’m happy that they’ve been making some changes and upgrades over the years.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2021

Review Text: Bought this in spite of the many warning reviews. Step one, connect the sync module to wifi. Result? 20 minutes of "Sending Wi-Fi info to Sync Module". From what I've read, it's not even worth contacting support. Returned. Bottom line? Don't bother.I bought two of these, so I decided to try the other one. Things only got worse. The back of the doorbell would not attach. Yes, even the purely physical part of this device didn't work. Called Blink support and they immediately diagnosed it as an ongoing problem with, I assume, many of the backs and they offered to send a new back. Switched the back on this with the other one and finally got it closed. Surely everything would work now, right?WRONG! After all that work, it turned out the camera in this doorbell didn't work. Called support again and after a few minutes I was told that a system reboot had been done and I was confidently assured that in 8-10 minutes everything would be perfect. It never was and it never worked. Returned!Seriously, save the time and aggravation and don't order this product. Blink once made really good stuff, but apparently under Amazon's ownership that is no longer the case.

Review Text: I have it set up using battery.  Initially I thought this was working good.  It recorded cars driving past my house.  The recording started when the cars was about halfway across the screen.  I've walking outside and it recorded me, and it recorded me going to the house.In looking at the videos for the day, I see a car in my driveway.  I don't see any videos of it going into my driveway, the car just appears.  Then a few hours later, the car is gone.  I don't see it leave, its just not there anymore.  I ordered some food from Uber Eats.  There is no recording of anyone coming to my door, or leaving.  But yet the food was outside my door.  During the day, my porch light is off, and before it gets dark, it turns on.  So near my door, the lighting should be good.  I don't have to depend on the nightvision .  I will keep working with this, but for now, I am not impressed by it.  I would have at least hoped it recorded someone coming up to my door to drop off a package and leave.

Review Title: Need to keep an eye on security at two locations
Review Text: I have a very love/hate relationship with this system. It’s worth the read if you have an elderly parent/grandparent. Bare with me…..Likes: I love the convenience of the system. They are battery operated so essentially if you have Wi-Fi the cameras work. The picture is great and the battery life isn’t bad even when in “alarmed” mode and utilized multiple times a day. This works great for keeping an eye on my grandma and keeping her home as long as possible. It creates a sense of comfort so I can check in on her multiple times a day and make sure she is safe.Dislikes: The cameras can have quite a bit of delay. Sometimes by the time I’m notified of someone in my driveway, they’re already out of their car and standing at the door. I’m hoping the doorbell will help with this.My biggest downside, while I know this won’t be an inconvenience or issue for most it is a huge negative for my family and I and our situation. Let me explain….My elderly grandma still lives at home. We like to keep an eye on her. So myself, my dad and my aunt all have access to her account.I like the camera system enough that I invested in the system myself for my home. Here lies the issue. I’d like to be able to receive notifications from both locations. In order to do this, I need both on the same account. When I do that, my dad and aunt also have access to see my cameras which I don’t want.  The only other option is to log in and out of each account. My grandmas account is set up under her phone number. Every time I log off I need to “verify” the account with a text code that is sent to her. My grandma is 84 and doesn’t know how to text. The other option is to choose which house I’d like to watch for the day. How do you choose 🤷🏻‍♀️I really hope that blink will look into this and create a way where I can possibly keep both accounts logged in, receive notifications from both locations and not have my dad know every time my mom (his ex-wife) comes over to visit.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2021

Review Title: Nice but very hard to install.
Review Text: The blink doorbell looks very much like others. It takes a good picture and the ability to ring our existing doorbell is a plus. Connecting the camera is similar to their other products. Everything went well during the installation up to mounting the button/camera to the wall mount. It was very frustrating trying to get the unit to "Snap on with minimal pressure" as the directions claimed. I had to repeatedly remove the plate and remount it before I got it to "snap on". I was afraid I was going to break the tiny plastic clips that hold it together. This feature needs rework to make it fit better. Another issue was a "corner" mount that was mentioned in the install instructions but was not in the box. I think that piece might have provided a better base and made snaping the plate to the camera easier.I will update this in a month after I have had some experience with the product.

Review Text: I am a long-time user of Blink, meaning I am in the "grandfathered" set of customers with free, limited cloud storage for video.  Overall, I think if you are already a Blink customer, this is a good addition to your system.Install: I needed one of those "wedges" that turns the camera to face out and using that, the install was pretty simple.  I agree with the people that noted that the back plate it comes with (which you still use when installing the wedge) is a little cheap and janky.  But the wedge is more sturdy and the resulting install is probably a little bit more solid and better than if I had just mounted the flat plate to the wall.You do need a good sized piece of flat wood to screw everything into.  This is not going to mount well to raw siding, curved trim pieces around doors etc.  You'd have to attach a small board to the surface of anything like that and then mount it to that board.Power vs. batteries:  I have one of those wired doorbells that is old-school, with the metal strikers that hit little chimes, not a digital doorbell.  This apparently matters because you need more power and a slightly larger transformer to drive one of those doorbells.  In turn, that means the transformer has enough power to power the blink doorbell.  If you have a digital doorbell you may (or may not) need to rely on the battery for the cameras.  It all depends on how big the transformer for your existing, wired doorbell is.  During the setup it asks you what kind of doorbell you have, and has a fairly sophisticated set of settings to make sure that when it sends a signal to the physical doorbell it is sending the correct amount of power to strike the chimes correctly.Set-up: Very easy and painless, almost exactly the same as setting up a regular blink camera.  Put in the batteries, scan the QR code, it finds the camera, links it to your existing system/sync module and you are ready to go.Motion Sensor: If you are already pretty familiar with Blink cameras, you know they can come with one of two kinds of sensors to detect motion.  Camera based sensors that just detect changes in the picture and more traditional sensors that only detect actual, physical movement.  The cheaper Blink mini only has a camera based sensor, while the more expensive units only detect actual physical movement with a dedicated motion sensor.  Both kinds of sensors can be triggered falsely by something like blowing leaves, but the camera-based sensors cannot distinguish changes in shadows and light from actual movement and so they have much higher rates of false detection.  Unfortunately, the blink doorbell appears to only have the cheaper detector that can be fooled by changes in light.  It does, however, have a more sophisticated, narrower grid of zones you can exclude from movement than the older Blink mini.  How much this matters to you is going to depend on where you plan to stick the camera - if you point your doorbell camera directly at a busy road and don't lock out the parts of the image that covers the road, you will get constant alerts from every car that goes by, or every person walking on the sidewalk, etc.  So think carefully about where the camera will sit and whether you want one of those wedges to tilt the direction of the thing to keep the camera aimed only at places where you actually want it to detect motion.Video quality: Very good, with a wide angle, almost fish-eye lens, so you get very good broad coverage of the area you are pointing the camera at.  There is also a microphone that records sound while you are recording video and it seems to work ok as well.  In theory you can use the thing to have a two-way conversation with whoever is at the door, but I haven't tried that yet.  I am, overall, very happy with the camera quality for the price here.Sound Chime/notifications:  When you push the doorbell, a chime inside the module itself goes off.  It is reasonably loud and lets the person ringing the doorbell know they definitely rang it.  The light on the button also lights up briefly to confirm the chime was pressed.  Would you, sitting inside the house, hear the chime the doorbell makes outside?  Probably, if you are in a small, quiet house.  Would you hear it  down in the basement of a large house with the TV or music on?  Absolutely not.  So if you are not hooking this up to an existing doorbell with a properly loud internal chime, then you will want to have it hooked up to your Alexa.  I don't use Alexa so didn't test that feature.  You do get a notification on your phone, when somebody rings the bell,  but I think most people will want either a hard wired connection or an Alexa connected to this thing to make sure they always hear the doorbell.What don't I like?I wish it had the same motion detection sensors as the larger blink cameras.  I would have paid more to get that.  Because it uses the camera to sense motion there are places where it really won't give good results.  So think very carefully about where you will place this, how often the wind will blow trees and create moving shadows within the motion detection zone, etc.It is annoying that even when the device is hard-wired, the light around the doorbell button isn't constantly lit.  Just as if it were only running on batteries, it only lights up when you press the button.  Not a huge deal in my installation, but if you don't have a porch light on, your doorbell will not be obvious to visitors.  It is particularly odd that they put a red LED into the thing which apparently has no purpose other than in the initial setup.  The design would be much better if the lighted ring around the button was always lit and then it flashed or turned red when you pressed it.  It appears all of the hardware necessary to do that is in the device, but it is not programmed that way.  I get that when the device isn't hardwired you don't want the button lit, but when it is powered it really should be lit in the dark.For $50, this thing is ok.  If you get it on sale, then it is a good deal, at least if you are an existing Blink customer.I am surprised that they killed off the little bit of free cloud storage for new customers.  That can't cost very much to provide these days and it was the key differentiator between Blink and some of these other companies that provide more elaborate, high-priced options.  Blink's claim to fame is that it works well enough and is cheap.  But if you have to pay a bunch of money for cloud storage no matter what, I would probably look at the more expensive options vs. Blink.  It stops being a compelling value once you start having to pay for video storage.
Review posted time: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2022

Review Text: This is a follow up review to a one star review that I gave on this doorbell camera. After submitting the one star, I was contacted by Blink about the review. Long story short, they provided me with a brand new camera free of charge.
